properties.information_summary: The recommended project consists of two hydroelectric systems with a total capacity of 160 kilowatts (kW). The upper system diverts up to five cubic feet per second (cfs) of water from Crooked Creek to Jims Lake where it is run through a 35 kW power recovery turbine. The lower system diverts up to seven cfs of water from Jims Lake to a 125kW turbine located at tidewater.

properties.information_summary: Evaluation of power potential of the project by diversion of water southeasterly to the McArthur River via a tunnel about 10-miles long, or easterly down the Chakachatna valley either by a tunnel about 12-miles long or by a dam and tunnel development.  The Chakachatna alignment is unfavorable due to adverse foundation conditions and nearby active volcano.
properties.environmental_concerns: anadromous and resident fish population in the Chakachatna River; area is habitat for moose, bear, coyote, 56 species of birds.
properties.flow_cfs: 3,547 cfs mean annual inflow from January 1960 through December 1970.

properties.transmission_line: Paired 230 kV single circuit lines with same capacity as peak capability of power plant
properties.installed_capacity_kw: 330 MW if 19% of inflow is reserved for maintaining downstream water level
properties.non_viable: Both powerhouse sites are near the Castle Mountain Fault and active volcano; preferred alternative (B) is diversion of flow from Chakachamna Lake to the McArthur valley with 19% provisional discharge to maintain fishery resource in Chakachatna River.

properties.non_viable: System would only be operational 6 or 7 months of the year and could not compete with existing diesel fueled generation system.
